title: Understanding the Problem
text: To find the pH of a weak acid solution, we need to use the acid dissociation constant (Ka) and the initial concentration of the acid. The formula for Ka is: Ka $$=$$ $$\frac{[H+][A-]/[HA][H+][A-]/[HA]}{[H+][A-]/[HA]}$$.

title: Setting Up the Mass Balance Equation
text: The mass balance equation for the weak acid HA is: $$[HA]_{initial}$$ $$=$$ [HA] + [A-]. This equation helps us relate the initial concentration of the acid to the concentrations of the dissociated and undissociated forms.

title: Using the Ka Expression
text: Substitute the expressions for $$[H+]$$ and [A-] from the mass balance into the Ka expression: Ka $$=$$ [H+]**2/([HA]_initial - [H+]).

title: Solving for $$[H+]$$
text: Rearrange the equation to solve for $$[H+]$$: $${[H+]}^2$$ $$=$$ Ka * ([HA]_initial - [H+]). This is a quadratic equation in terms of $$[H+]$$.

title: Solving the Quadratic Equation
text: Use the quadratic formula to solve for $$[H+]$$: $$[H+]$$ $$=$$ $$(-b$$ $$\frac{plus}{minus}$$ sqrt(b**2 - 4ac))/(2a), where a $$=$$ $$1$$, $$b$$ $$=$$ -Ka, and c $$=$$ $$-Ka [HA]_{initial}$$.

title: Calculating the pH
text: Once you have $$[H+]$$, calculate the pH using the formula: pH $$=$$ $$-log[H+]$$.

title: Final pH Calculation
text: Substitute the value of $$[H+]$$ into the pH formula: pH $$=$$ $$-\ln\left(0.00355\right)$$.
